titleproper.value:
Preliminary Inventory to the Sandi L. Wisenberg Research Files for "Reds: A Generation of Radicals Fades Away on Miami Beach"
                    <num>TAM.582</num>

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T20:04-0400</date>

unittitle.value: Sandi L. Wisenberg Research Files for "Reds: A Generation of Radicals Fades Away on Miami Beach"

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Sandi L. Wisenberg, journalist and author, was a features writer for the 
                <emph render="italic">Miami Herald</emph>, for which she wrote "Reds: A Generation of American Radicals Fads Away on Miami Beach" (July, 21, 1985). The collection contains Wisenberg's reseach files for "Reds: A Generation of Radicals Fades Away on Miami Beach," including files labeled with the first names of the individuals featured. The files include including notebooks, drafts, clippings and other printed ephemera, and a dozen audiocassettes, principally interviews with the subjects of her article.

p.value: Open for research without restrictions, except for the interviews. User copies of the (audiocassette) interviews may be requested, which must be listened to at the Library, and which may be cited, but not quoted.

Sandi L. Wisenberg, journalist and author, was a features writer for the 
                <emph render="italic">Miami Herald</emph>, for which she wrote "Reds: A Generation of American Radicals Fades Away on Miami Beach" (July, 21, 1985). Wisenberg also wrote 
                <emph render="italic">Holocaust Girls: History, Memory and Other Obsessions</emph> (2002), and 
                <emph render="italic">The Adventures of Cancer Bitch</emph> (2009). For more biographical information, see her website (http://slwisenberg.blogspot.com/).

The collection contains Wisenberg's reseach files for "Reds: A Generation of Radicals Fades Away on Miami Beach," including files labeled with the first names of the individuals featured. The files include including notebooks, drafts, clippings and other printed ephemera, and a dozen audiocassettes, principally interviews with the subjects of her article.
